name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on Sophia's report in 't Veld on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a pan-European private pension product (PEPP) (COM(2017)0343 – C8-0219/2017 – 2017/0143(COD)) (A8-0278/2018).

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I am very pleased that today we will be able to vote finally on the PEPP as it is called, the pan-European personal pension product, because I think that we have delivered what we promised, a truly pan-European product that would be simple and safe and good for consumers and I think that that is what we have on the table.  First of all, to start with the pan-European nature. It is a regulation that lays down pan-European quality criteria, pan-European rights for consumers but also true pan-European oversight and the possibility for EIOPA to intervene, and I think that is something that was very important. Initially we wanted authorisation by EIOPA but I think that now, with the smart use of the existing powers of EIOPA, we have achieved the same goal.  We have also laid down extensive rights for consumers, protection for consumers, the right to information, compulsory advice, the right to switching, the right to, let’s say, portability rights; we have achieved a fee cap of 1%, which is no small achievement because there was massive resistance against it, and if you see the fees that are actually being charged today, a 1% fee cap is really very good. We have achieved a basic PEPP which is basically a kind of off—the—shelf product for anyone who is not financially literate and who is not rich, that we have set up with all the necessary safeguards. Nevertheless, we have all seen in recent days that there are still a lot of people who are concerned, and I would like to eliminate a couple of misunderstandings. First of all, PEPP is clearly a third pillar product. It is complementary, individual and voluntary. It in no way replaces the first or second pillar products, and I think it is important to realise that. I’ve received a lot of emails, as have most of the colleagues I suppose, in particular from Spain, accusing us of being a threat to the public pension systems. But that is really complete nonsense and I would like to state here that the only real threat to public pension systems are the national authorities, which are completely unable and unwilling to reform their systems, and if today PEPP is going to fill a gap in Member States where the pension provisions are inadequate, that is purely to blame on those national governments and not on PEPP. It will actually offer the opportunity to people who today do not have a proper pension provision to actually have something for the future. I would like to say that for me, creating a PEPP which is good for consumers was the prime concern, and I know that one of the objectives of the Commission was also to complete the capital markets union and if we have contributed to that with PEPP then I’m very happy, but for me creating something which is good for European citizens was actually the prime objective. I think that what we are going to vote on today will achieve that objective and further contribute to a social Europe that actually cares for people, and I hope that it’s going to command a very solid majority.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I really want to thank you for organising this very important debate on the pan-European personal pension product (PEPP). The PEPP regulation is a major milestone on the road to addressing pension gaps and democratic challenges and a major achievement in completing the capital markets union (CMU). It will benefit consumers and providers with a strong framework for personal pensions through a new product with strong consumer protection and enhanced cross-border competition. As the rapporteur said, it will not, by any means, replace public pension schemes. On the contrary, it offers new opportunities and alternatives to those who voluntarily want to use this scheme. Let me express my gratitude to the rapporteur, Ms Sophia in ’t Veld, who has invested a great deal of time and passion to make PEPP a reality. I also want to thank Mr Roberto Gualtieri, Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Policy (ECON) and the shadow rapporteurs, Mr Brian Hayes, Mr Renato Soru, Mr Bas Eickhout, Mr Ashley Fox, Mr Gerolf Annemans and Mr Dennis de Jong, for your constructive engagement, persistence and faith in this truly pan-European challenge. Finally, my thanks go to the rapporteurs of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), who have made extremely valuable contributions.  According to our data, across the EU, people retiring between now and 2057 will need to save an additional two trillion euro each year to achieve a sustainable income in retirement. At the same time, European markets for personal pension products are fragmented and uneven – in some parts of the Union, even non-existent. Only 67 million out of the total population of 243 million European citizens between 25 and 59 years old have currently invested in personal pension products. The PEPP will give all citizens the opportunity to save for their retirement on a purely voluntary basis. It will open up a genuine pan-European market for personal pension products, complementing public and occupational pension systems. Supplementary pensions can only become effective if they are accessible for all income brackets. The design of the PEPP will ensure that products offered are competitive and cost—effective, with strong protection for all savers. Personal pension providers will be able to sell the PEPP across the EU with one single registration, allowing savers to benefit from enhanced cross-border competition and economies of scale. The Commission hopes very much that Member States will follow this recommendation and grant PEPPs the same tax advantages as they grant similar national personal pension products, even if the PEPP doesn’t match in all the details the criteria set for the national product. I regret that the portability of the PEPP and the role of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) were considerably weakened in sometimes difficult negotiations. Having said that, I believe that this is an important first step towards building a true pan-European market for personal pension products. The PEPP is also one of the key measures of the Commission’s Action Plan to strengthen the capital markets union. It will channel savings towards long—term investments and benefit investment growth and jobs throughout the EU. Finally, I am well aware that important work remains to be done to define some key features of the PEPP, through delegated acts. The Commission will closely follow EIOPA’s work on these matters and make sure that the resulting delegated acts are fully consistent with the political orientation taken by the co-legislators.

name: Heinz K. Becker
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I have been one of several people in this Parliament who have fought for PEPP, and I thank the Commission for the initiative on this product. There is good news for Europe's younger generations, because pepP provides an additional pension for a better quality of life at the best age. In other regions of Europe, there are not as well developed social systems as, for example, in my own country. I believe that PEPP has a very good chance of fulfilling precisely this function there. At the same time, it has an added value in developed social systems to protect living standards. The private supplementary pension scheme PEPP, the pan-European pension product, will be available in various variants. I very much welcome the fact that, in a standardised eu-wide version, we have even managed to offer a kind of European capital guarantee, which offers a high degree of security for many people, where there are no sophisticated pension systems. PEPP is a transparent, attractive addition to the first and second pillars. I underline what Mrs in 't Veld – my colleague as rapporteur – said: it is not a competition with the first and second pillars, but an additional product, and as such it makes very valuable contributions to pensions. On behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I support the introduction of PEPP. We also offer customers standardized documentation, which also provides information about certification, for example. Here, the role of EIOPA is also accompanied by us with extraordinary sympathy. I think that we can offer the younger generations an excellent product for pensions.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I am pleased that we will be able to conclude this dossier during this parliamentary term. As draftsman of the opinion of the IMCO Committee, I would like to begin by warmly congratulating the rapporteur, Sophia in 't Veld. Thank you for the good and open cooperation! From the outset, the aim for me was to create a PEPP that is a simple, secure, transparent, consumer-friendly, cheap and long-term pension product, and we have been able to achieve this goal. Once the negotiations have been concluded, we can say in summary that we have made the Commission's proposal more suitable for the internal market and more consumer-friendly. The most important point, in my view, is the introduction of the basic PEPP. Each provider must offer one. It is important here that the basic PEPP can also be completed securely and cost-effectively via digital channels. My main concern was capital protection. The customer may under no circumstances lose his capital in the basic PEPP, nor may it be eaten up by fees or other charges. We have been able to achieve this because capital protection must always be sought – whether through a capital guarantee or through life-cycle risk reduction techniques. A PEPP is a pension product. This requirement is met by the fact that 35% of the capital in the basic PEPP must be paid out in the form of a lifetime pension. In the case of a base PEPP that is otherwise secured over the life cycle, a disbursement is to be made via a withdrawal plan. Support for the success of the PEPP is a prerequisite for the success of the PepP. Only they can provide for the same tax advantages that apply to comparable national products. I therefore welcome the amendments that do not allow the conditions for a PEPP to be less favourable than for national products. With this result, we are creating a genuine internal market for private pensions, which will benefit the young generation and people on low incomes in particular.

name: Brian Hayes
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, can I firstly congratulate Sophia in ’t Veld and all our colleagues who worked so closely with us to get this result today and to thank the Commission. Last year in my country, Ireland, 30 000 EU citizens came to work, because we have full employment in Ireland. Many of them are young people. Many of them have come to Ireland and worked for maybe four or five years and then go back to their home country or go to another country to work. It is crucially important that we get people saving earlier, as the Commissioner rightly said, and one of the advantages of PEPP now is that we have a pan-European product.  This is not the end of PEPP; this is the first step, we’re taking baby steps here today. But it’s an important first step in trying to get the message across. Those young people who are travelling to Ireland and elsewhere to work have the opportunity of buying into a pan-European pension. Secondly, it is important that this is part of the capital markets union. We need to get the connection going between investment and savers. That’s where the big problem is in Europe right now. From my perspective it was very important that this product was provided for by a multiple of providers. So it’s important that the insurance industry, asset managers and others are now able to provide this product on a pan-European basis. But I want to reiterate, this is a third pillar product. This is a voluntary product. It does not cut across in any way first or second pillar pension provision. This is a product that delivers on strong consumer protection. It delivers on giving citizens full transparency of costs and ESG policy. It ensures mandatory advice, strong contract requirements, rights of switching and a fee cap, and the product intervention powers of EIOPA and competent authorities.  We have made a good start with this proposal. It is not the end of the matter by any manner or means, but it certainly deals with the issue that we face in Europe, that we are going to have. It is anticipated that we will have one worker for every two pensioners by 2060. Currently there are four pensioners for every one worker. If we don’t encourage people to save we’re going to find our situation getting worse and worse over the years. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. First, I have to declare that after several years working with you, Brian, I have always had a great personal sympathy for you, even if we disagreed on a lot of substance. However, I have to say that our code of conduct says in Article 3.3 that, before speaking, any potential conflict of interest should be declared orally or in writing to the President. You have accepted, unfortunately, to leave that House in order to become CEO of the Irish Banks and Payments Federation. Have you declared the potential conflict of interest when dealing with this file?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I have.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Socialist Parliamentary Group is more critical of this proposal than the previous speakers. Personally, I am quite enthusiastic about this because we want to change the world, and one of the things we have wanted is the functioning of the internal market and greater mobility of people within the European Union. This pension product, the European pension product, is, as it were, promoting it. In this context, I have to say that what is most of what is coming from citizens at the moment is the criticism and fears for Europe and their own future, that once they have worked part of their careers in different parts of Europe, in different European countries, then the different pension systems will not adapt to this new situation. Unfortunately, however, this PEPP product has given rise to suspicions that this has something to do with the fears that this is usually linked to the deterioration of social security, but that is not the case. This is a good idea and the Committee on Consumer Protection has made a great deal of improvements in terms of this consumer protection. It is now important to maintain that these European ideas, which guarantee consumer protection and capital protection, are realised here, because the appeal of this product is precisely linked to the fact that this is European, Europeanly, when it comes to age, and if there are disappointments, then there will be disappointments in other things.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for One thing is certain – the pension, said former Federal Labour Minister Norbert Blüm. Today, nothing is safe. The pension is certainly not secure; neither the pay-as-you-go nor the funded pension is secure. The reason why the funded pension is no longer secure is the European Central Bank: there are no more interest rates, you can no longer make provision through savings. If there is no interest, then there is no pension in old age, at least no funded pension. PEPP does not change this major error in our central bank's monetary policy. It is all very well to incentivise you to save money. But if there is no interest, then the incentive is minimal. What the European Parliament is doing here is a trifle compared to the damage done by the European Central Bank's interest rate policy. But the way it is done here is also being tackled incorrectly. This PEPP is overcomplicated. It is non-transparent and it is overpriced, so it cannot reasonably be successful on the market. I only look at what is being imposed here in the area of counselling: mandatory advice from sellers, everyone knows that they are actually completely unqualified for advice. And thank you very much, Mr Giegold, for pointing out the conflicts of interest. Who has the biggest conflict of interest? These are precisely the sellers of these products, which the European Parliament is now also tasked with advising. This advice is useless, superfluous, and making it mandatory makes the product expensive and incapable of market. It's going to be a flop, So sorry I'm.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to congratulate all the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, in particular those of the Committee on Employment, where I also contributed to this PEPP. I want to say that it is a complex and technical issue that we are dealing with here, and that we can even talk about the error of the ECB's monetary policy. You don't have to go that far. This has the ambition it has. The ambition of the Chair of the Employment Working Group from day one is to help, facilitate, increase the chances of a decent pension for people who have not been able to be covered, for historical reasons, reasonably in the course of their lives, by their country's public pension systems or who have pensions that are too low Et cetera. And, therefore, it is a problem of Europe's willingness to better protect our elders socially. We discuss whether the capital guarantee is sufficient or not. All right, let's hope we get better. Is Europe's presence sufficient with EIOPA? We would have liked something better, but it is undoubtedly a socially positive instrument. And few jokes say this attacks public funds or pensions. That's alarming uselessly and demagogigically.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Poverty-proof retirement provision requires strong statutory pension systems, good wages and a high level of employment. A United Nations study, which was also published during the negotiations on the PEPP, has also shown that the privatisation of pensions is an aberration. This study ultimately calls for the strengthening of the statutory pension and the cessation of privatisation. But PEPP is not only politically wrong, but also badly done. There is no guarantee for buyers that they will end up getting what they deposit out of. The fees are too high and PEPP is distributed by asset managers and hedge funds. PEPP therefore does not benefit the younger, low-income, or the twenty percent of the European population, who are already at risk of or affected by old-age poverty. Linking social security to financial markets is demonstrably a mistake. That is why my group and I have tabled a motion to reject PEPP, because we are opposed to the privatisation of pensions.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for all her great work on this product. Probably the most important thing to stress is that there are private pension products on the European markets and they are unregulated. So, what we’re doing here is finally regulating private pension products. I think the best thing that we are doing here is to create a basic pan—European private pension product that has rules to protect consumers, rather than give money away to all kinds of hedge funds. And, of course, you can criticise these rules, but what I think is very important is that we have a cap on the total fee. We really need to make sure – and this is also a question to the Commission – that this cap is really at 1% of the overall costs. That is a very important statement to make. One final point: we all know that this does not replace basic pensions but I do think that the Commission needs to become very clear that they are not, in their austerity programme of the future, pushing further cuts of the first pillar. The first pillar can then remain and we can have a third additional, rather than replacement, pillar.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, the Dutch Parliament opposes the European pension product, the PEPP. That PEPP requires a substantial change in the law in the Netherlands and the subsequent Dutch vote against the Minister in the Council was in vain. As usual, the majority of votes are in European legislation and decision-making. The Netherlands was therefore alone. However, Article 114(2) of the Treaty states that the Commission must not interfere in tax provisions and in the rights and interests of workers. I therefore asked the European Commission questions two months ago, questions to which the Commission has still not been able to find an answer. After all, why does the Commission think it should be allowed to interfere and why these majority decisions, which are always at the expense of our employees? The Dutch funded occupational pensions are unique!  My concerns and those of the Dutch Parliament are shared by the Dutch pension federation. The introduction of the PEPP threatens to undermine the Dutch pension system. This is the third time that the Netherlands' desire to keep its own pension system out of the EU's control has been ignored by the Union. Why not encourage a supplementary pension without sacrificing the sovereignty of the Member States? Because if financially sustainable national pension systems are so vital to the stability of the Union, as the rapporteur points out, that is precisely an argument for keeping the Union far from the pension systems of the Member States! After all, pensions from the third pillar must be tailor-made for the situation in each Member State precisely because there are major differences between Member States. And that has not been taken into account. EU interference only gives administrative ballast, loss of sovereignty and erosion of the position of the Dutch worker. The PVV will therefore vote against this proposal.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Madam President, the pan-European individual insurance product decided today is a pan-European tombstone in social security, a risk of death for workers, especially young people. A major obstacle to the profitability and competitiveness of capital, i.e. conquests in pensions and health, public social security after years of cuts are being flattened. Businesses and the state are not only exempt from their burden but are profiting on the backs of workers. It's pure private insurance, a supplement to state hunger pensions for an actively aging job, if you're left to invest on broken wages. No guarantee at all that you'll get back what you gave. All stock market gambling reserves, free financing of big business. Another gift to these banks and private insurance companies. Alarm now for workers, old and new. Black on the real front of neoliberal social democrats, supposedly left-wing SYRIZA types who hide their idy face here too with fake dipoles and dilemmas. Class struggle and support of communists is the only guarantee for social security and labour rights.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am among the Members who support this proposal. I want to subscribe to it, I want to say that the concerns of some colleagues who fear that this product would undermine national pension systems are completely odd.  It has been made clear here that this is a product that is complementary, which will allow citizens another choice when thinking about how to secure money for old age, and if we are expanding the amount of private banking products for pension insurance, that is only good in my opinion. Here we are creating another option for our citizens to save for retirement. We are creating another private pension product here under the third pillar, thus not undermining the national existing pension systems. This needs to be realised, so I find the concerns that some colleagues here are venting to be absolutely odd, and no one here is talking about the unification of the European pension system and the dismantling of national specificities. I very much welcome this proposal, it is an alarming number for me that only about a quarter of middle-aged people in Europe save under private banking pension schemes. This is a very small number, because in the future, for today's productive generation, dads will not be able to provide a sufficiently high pension through the ongoing financial system. So it makes sense that we are thinking about how to strengthen the will of middle-class people to save more for retirement, and this instrument can help to do that. On the contrary, I want to say one thing, I would like the instrument to be more ambitious. Here I am a little criticised by the Commission and the Council for not being able to agree on a banking and, above all, tax advantage for this product. I think that if there was a tax advantage that was at least competitive with national products, it would be more attractive to citizens.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, with regard to the issue of pensions, I think that when we talk about pensions in Europe today, we have a better interest in talking about the first pillar of pensions, which is to ensure that everyone can benefit from a sufficiently paid pension at the end of their careers. Talking today about a private pension pillar, that is, the third pillar of pensions, with the idea that this third pillar of pensions will be able to deal with the issue of the first pillar of pension, seems to me to be the wrong dynamic. All the more so since the recommendations made in the context of the European semester often state that the European Commission is proposing that Member States reduce their spending on pensions under the first pillar. We see that the logic would be to transfer to a third pillar, that is, a private pension. The debate we have today therefore seems to me to be quite special in that our priority should be to this first pillar. Secondly, with regard to the private pension pillar as proposed today, we see that there are a number of difficulties, the main of which is to say that this portability can be done on two Member States, whereas it is described as a pan-European tool. Finally, the last point I would like to make concerns the issue of tax evasion, which can be organised by this pillar of pension, which is a pillar of private pension: it is possible to contribute in one country and receive one's pension in another country, choosing the country that is the most tax-efficient. It seems to me, therefore, that this proposal which is on the table today does not address the current pension problems in Europe and, above all, promotes the issue of tax evasion concerning capitalisation. For this reason, I will not vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it’s my pleasure to see that this Chamber will hopefully manage to get into this scheme and help Europeans get into the pan-European pension schemes in a good way. Today, selling and trading goods and some services in the single market is normal but as this file shows, when it comes to capital, there is still some way to go. Bringing in this pan-European personal pension product will make it easier to save, and the private pension plan will get you a pension in countries where this is not possible today, and to use it without any problems if you move or go to another country.  I believe this is great news for European citizens. It is not a mandatory scheme, it is a third pillar, it is voluntary, it does not replace existing schemes, it just complements them, and it will help both consumers and providers.  So I don’t see the problem in this. It has taken decades, I know, almost a decade to get it done, and I notice the resistance from both the financial industry in some countries, and from some countries, but for me this is the best proof that this is good for competition and its consequences for the citizens as well. What does it do? It will make it possible for the citizen who cannot get a decent pension in some countries today to get one – it will make it more flexible, portable, easy, comprehensible and, surely, cheaper for most of the European countries and for the citizens in them. This is what the single market and the EU can do for them. I think we should be proud.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, under the myth — which you yourselves have created — of the unsustainability of public pensions, you promote a product that opens a new front for speculative business in Europe. A financial product that can never be a guarantee for citizens and only benefits, through tax advantages, the richest and the banking business, channeling the small savings of European workers into financial markets. You just want to expand the single capital market with gigantic pension funds capable of intervening in the global financial system The duty of the European Union and states should be to protect citizens, and you breach this principle by enhancing high-risk private systems that do not even have a capital guarantee in real terms. Do you really want to protect citizens? For the only way is to strengthen public pension systems, which are the largest and the only mechanism to combat poverty.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have heard a lot of confused arguments here that speak out against this pension product. It is completely indisputable that the statutory pension is the pillar of old-age pensions, and for good reasons, this product does not put any tax advantage, no financial advantage, into the private pillar of pension provision. For good reasons, we should not, because public support should be concentrated on the statutory pension. On the other hand, we have a widespread rip-off of private pension products, and this European regulation will limit this rip-off. This is a step forward, especially for workers and small people who do not get the best financial products on the capital market. I really do not know what we should have against it. And the whole thing has nothing to do with tax evasion, ladies and gentlemen. Because if you have earned a pension in one country and then move to another country, it is not a tax evasion, but simply the freedom where you are looking for residence. So here everything is messed up to fight against this product. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Arena (S&D)
text: 'blue card' question. Mr. Giegold, when you say "little people," I would like to know who you are talking about. When you earn 1,200 euros a month, do you think you have enough to pay a pension fund to guarantee your retirement at age 65? No. You say there is no tax evasion. However, we have asked that, in this process, the pension, when it is taken over by capitalization, be taxed in the country where you contributed, something we did not get. Therefore, when you take out your pension fund, you do so in the country that is the most tax-efficient. So your argument is, in my view, a rich argument that does not hold up.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. That was roaring very loudly. But I have to say that the point is this: first of all, small people start for me earlier than at EUR 1 200. There are many ordinary workers who put something aside, and why should they pay excessive fees? Thanks to this European regulation, these charges will fall, and that is a good thing. But what you are arguing is a kind of , let me say it this way – pension nationalism. This means that if you have paid a pension in a country, then you should stay there and enjoy it there. I think it is okay for a Frenchman to want to live in Spain after retirement; that is perfectly fine. And if the systems there are different, they are different. But that is freedom in Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, the Union's primary concern must be respect for citizens and the effort of their work. Our aim is to limit privatisation and strengthen public universal social security systems. However, a purely investment product, compulsory for the Member States, is being promoted, which will even benefit from tax incentives and reliefs. The principles of a fair and sustainable system are simple: compulsory insurance, guaranteed adequate pension, proportionality and stability of contributions, remunerative benefits, support for continuity of contributions in redistribution terms, long-term structured savings and the creation of reserves, so that the state pension system is sustainable and decent for citizens. Of course, every citizen should have the right to choose any additional private voluntary pension options, but the state has a substantial obligation to establish a regulatory framework with appropriate rules in order to avoid creating unfair competition to the detriment of the state system.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's vote in this House on the PEPP, a pan-European third pillar pension product, that is, additional and supplementary to public pensions, is an extremely important vote.  On the financial side, PPPs can provide an opportunity to channel private savings into productive investment, thereby helping to stimulate economic growth and thus making the Capital Markets Union move forward in a concrete way. On the social front, however, PPPs can play an important role in combating the growing pension gap in our society. However, these new pension products must be of high quality, highly competitive and sufficiently attractive to the public. It is a good thing that a European instrument should finally be set up to help the growing number of workers, especially young people, living and working in the European Union outside their country of origin, thus enabling them to activate a single supplementary pension product, without having to rejoin the different periods of contributions paid in the various Member States.  I must, however, point out a serious critical element in the text that emerged from the trialogue, namely the lack of an adequate role for the European Supervisory Authority for Insurance and Occupational Pensions in the delicate authorisation phase of PEPP providers. So I believe that, in order to make this instrument work properly, it will be necessary to make adjustments and changes in the future.

name: Caroline Nagtegaal (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I was elected by the Dutch and that was to give a boost to the internal market and also to bring some more Rotterdam mentality to Brussels. And to protect all the beauty we have built up in Europe. And one of those Dutch achievements that we have and which I will always stand for is our pension system, that huge pot of more than 1 300 billion euros, saved up by millions of Dutch people for their well-deserved old age. More than half of Europe's pension assets have been saved by the Dutch, with hard work and with a view to the future. I am opposed to a new European pension product, because in my view this will lead to more European interference in our pensions. Because for me it is actually in that sense: the only ones who have something to say about our pension money, that is us, the Dutch themselves!

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, pensioners are sick of hearing the European institutions say that public pension systems are not sustainable. We are talking about people who have worked their whole lives to be able to have a dignified retirement, and as a society we are obliged to guarantee their pensions. It's not a question of benefits, it's about rights. Ladies and gentlemen, pensioners do not need to play casino with their pensions or invent new financial products which all they do is allow them to do business with their savings. What they need is for the European Union to commit decisively to ensuring public pension systems and to stop promoting their privatisation. From here, all our support for so many struggling pensioners who are working, who are demonstrating, who are defending the rights of all and all. Not their rights, but those of all and all. We defend public pensions.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, this week, members of the European Parliament have received more than twenty thousand emails from pensioners , particularly the Spanish State - who asked us to vote against this product. Of course, you will have my vote against and that of the organization I represent here. Worthy pensions, because for a person who has a pension of four hundred euros — as there are many cases in my land — and six hundred, and seven hundred — those are already considered high - it will be very difficult to access this product, Commissioner. It's going to be very difficult. Moreover, the European Parliament does not have powers in tax matters, so this product hides, again, a trap. Because, having suffered numerous cuts because of the imposition of the troika's decision and, moreover, because of the successive pension reforms we have had, particularly promoted by the People's Party in Spain, our pensioners are under their diminished rights and we do not know whether future generations will have pensions. This will result in this product benefiting higher incomes and resulting in a huge loss of public revenue that could be earmarked for other social policies, such as job creation, aid to the most disadvantaged and also to dependence. Hence my vote against and my support for pensioners.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: Mr President, the Capital Markets Union has begun this mandate. Thirteen proposals have been made by the Commission, 10 of which have been put forward. Of the proposals that are being adopted, such as the PEPP, it is questionable whether they really contribute to the capital markets union. The next period will really have to do better.  I understand that Parliament has been working hard to improve the proposal, but it does raise the question: what is so pan-European about the product if the monitoring remains national? That's what's going on with the whole capital markets union. And to what extent does a voluntary product contribute to pension building in countries that do not yet have it? Why should we actually be interested in a pension product at a time when interest rates are low and saving is not actually paying off? In the Netherlands you are inclined to say: do not benefit, then it does not harm. But that seems a little too cynical for European legislation. That is why the Labour Party is voting against the PEPP.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress from the outset that, after hearing what has been said here and the various parties, I will vote in favour of this proposal because I believe that it will not compete with national systems. It will, yes, open the door to people who have made savings to have a new system, another complementary system, not competing with national systems, but complementary.  This is not for everyone, nor does it even call into question the national systems that could continue to operate with the universal compulsory model contributing to all. This is for those people who now make some savings, some saver, and who sometimes invest it in bad investments and bad products and who can now invest a little better in their future. Therefore, I think that this proposal is good and is precisely intended to complement and not to compete with national systems.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, just before the elections, what message will the European Parliament send to the citizens? What does he want to do, at the end of our term, richer the big players in the markets with the savings of the workers? The European Council is in a hurry to boost markets with the savings of workers struggling with their old age. On the other hand, governments cannot even agree on workers' allowances when they move from country to country. I call on you to reflect and commit to strengthening the public pension by voting against the pan-European private pension.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I find this pan-European product of individual pensions an insult to the working class, an insult to young precarious people, an insult to women, an insult to so many people who are not employed. I believe that in order to really ensure public pension and decent pension systems we have to vote 'no' on this pan-European individual pension product and get to work on measures and a regulation that really helps States strengthen these public pension systems and have decent pensions. Our future — that in old age we have a dignified life – cannot depend on whether we have the capacity to save. I also find it unethical to allocate public money to support these individual pension products with tax advantages. It's transferring public money to the coffers of the business from which they're going to sell these products.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for a very enlightening and good – slightly heated – debate on this very important matter.  First, I want to make clear that the most important thing for everyone is that our public pension systems are robust and can deliver what they are meant to deliver. In many Member States – if not in all – we have to pay attention to reforming the public pension systems in order to make them strong, even in an era where the number of aging people in our societies is increasing significantly. So we have to do everything possible to strengthen public pension schemes.  But this particular product, PEPP, has nothing to do with public pension schemes. It does not replace public pension schemes. It only increases the alternatives available for ordinary citizens. In many of our Member States, if you look at statistics, people who have temporary jobs – not permanent decade—long careers, but a temporary job – sometimes with quite low salaries, have wanted to complement their public pensions by taking a private pension product, and now what we are doing is increasing alternatives. We are creating regulations and rules for existing European pension products. Is this wrong? I don’t think so. It’s positive, because it may lead to greater competition between service providers and it usually leads to better quality, safer and cheaper products for end consumers.  I have seen that this issue is very easy to use for disinformation, spreading messages that we are privatising public pension schemes. Everybody should know that this is not true; even food is sold in private companies. So I am sure that, even though there are different ideologies and different priorities, there is no one in this Chamber who would like to spread disinformation to our voters, because it’s not worth it. It’s not responsible. It’s better to explain what this proposal and this product really does in our societies and, at the same time, to convey messages that we have to be responsible and also make sure that our public pension schemes are in good shape, also in the future when there will be fewer people of working age and more people retiring and enjoying public pension schemes.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank those colleagues who spoke in support and I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the Presidencies, in particular the Austrians, who have contributed to this, and the Commission.  But I would like to say to those colleagues who spoke very negatively and who are going to vote against – most of whom have actually already left the room, because they’re clearly not interested in hearing arguments! But I’ve heard a lot of fake news in this debate, as the Commissioner said. For example, saying that if you vote against then you can keep these personal pension savings products off the markets – that’s rubbish. Those who are going to vote against should know that they’re actually going to help the cowboys on the market, because they are on the market, and this is, as Bas Eickhout rightfully said, the only way of regulating. Secondly, I heard that if you vote ‘For’, you’re going to weaken the public pension systems – rubbish! Complete and utter rubbish! They are completely different systems. And to those colleagues who are going to vote against: you know what you should do? Rather than voting against a good PEPP regulation with consumer protection, address your national governments and tell them that they should reform and strengthen the public systems because it’s completely unrelated to PEPP, and if the public systems are weak it’s because the national governments are not doing anything about it.  And then finally to my Dutch colleagues, I’m going to switch to Dutch. Vandaag hadden we weer het broodje-aapverhaal: zodra je in Europa het woord pensioen noemt, betekent dat dat Europa met zijn tengels aan de Nederlandse pensioenspaarpotten gaat zitten! Broodje aap, broodje aap, broodje aap! Beste collega’s van de PvdA, de PVV en de VVD: onzin, klinkklare onzin! Alleen maar voor de koppen in De Telegraaf!  And finally, I heard that if we vote for the PEPP that’s going to lead to tax evasion. Sorry! The PEPP regulation has got absolutely zero to do with tax policies. To Ms Arena, who is now back, it doesn’t change the tax policies at all. It is nonsense! Read the regulation. The regulation is merely about setting standards – consumer protection standards – for products which are on the market. That’s all it is doing. You should welcome it! We have taken on board all the amendments of your Group, which wasn’t always represented in the negotiations, except by Mr Gualtieri who did an excellent job, so the S&D Group should be able to support this.
